title: Democrats Push Elizabeth Warren for Plan to Pay for Medicare for All
text:
Sen. Elizabeth Warren has been dogged from the debate stage to town halls to late-night TV shows by questions about whether she plans to unveil a signature health-care proposal—and how she would pay for expanding government-run insurance.

Health care consistently polls as the No. 1 issue Democratic voters are concerned about. But unlike her top rivals, Ms. Warren hasn’t detailed her preferred policies, instead saying she’s “with Bernie” Sanders in supporting a government-run Medicare for All system.

Ms. Warren’s top aides have called at least one expert on single-payer health-care programs in recent weeks to discuss the costs involved. Her campaign declined to say whether it is crafting its own health-care proposal.

Now, she is contesting former Vice President Joe Biden’s advantage or leading in polls of the field ahead of Tuesday’s debate in Ohio. Democratic presidential campaigns are turning up the pressure on Ms. Warren to explain what she supports and how she will pay for it.

“I think you should be straightforward about what your plan is going to do,” South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg said in a recent interview with The Wall Street Journal. “And we haven’t seen that.”

Mr. Buttigieg, who has also called Ms. Warren “extremely evasive,” has aired an ad promoting his “Medicare For All Who Want It” health care plan and stressed in interviews that his plan wouldn’t increase taxes for the middle class. Mr. Sanders has said his Medicare for All proposal would increase taxes but lower premiums. Ms. Warren hasn’t been so specific about how she would pay for expanding government-run health insurance.

Ms. Warren co-sponsored Mr. Sanders’s Medicare for All bill in the Senate, and she has repeatedly praised the legislation, even as other candidates, such as California Sen. Kamala Harris, have backed away from it after endorsing it in the Senate.

“‘I’m with Bernie’ is actually the most respectful position she could have,” said Adam Green, a Warren ally, adding “there is a strategy there.”

Mr. Green, co-founder of a liberal PAC, the Progressive Campaign Change Committee, said Ms. Warren supports Medicare for All as a goal but thinks how to get there is still up for debate. “At this point, she’s the only candidate left standing who is with him on Medicare for All, meaning she will actually fight for a true version of it,” Mr. Green said.

Ms. Warren discussed Medicare for All legislation with Sen. Bernie Sanders on Capitol Hill last year. Ms. Warren called Medicare for All a ‘framework’ at a recent town hall. Photo: jim watson/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

Ms. Warren called Medicare for All “a framework” that “doesn’t have the details” at a recent town hall in New Hampshire, prompting criticism from the Sanders campaign.

"It’s not a framework. It’s a 100-page bill,” Mr. Sanders’ senior policy adviser Warren Gunnels tweeted in response. Mr. Sanders has mostly held off directly criticizing Ms. Warren.

Ms. Warren frequently talks on the campaign trail about how her proposed wealth tax would pay for student-loan debt cancellation and several other priorities. She has also outlined other ways to pay for new programs, such as using taxes on high-income Americans to extend the life of the Social Security trust fund.

But on health care, she speaks with less specificity. “The overall structure is that the very wealthy and big corporations will see their costs go up, but middle-class families will see their costs go down,” Ms. Warren told reporters in Los Angeles last week. “That is how [middle-class families] frame the problem: what their costs will be. And their costs will go down.”

Ms. Warren hasn’t said whether middle-class taxes would increase because the exact cost of Medicare for All is unclear, given that there are several versions of the framework produced by lawmakers and economists, according to a person familiar with the senator’s thinking. This person said the senator has chosen to stick to the broader principle that overall costs will go down and that the wealthy will pay more.

Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and a supporter of Medicare for All, said all of the prominent proposals would lead to some increase in taxes for most Americans. However, he agreed with Ms. Warren that most Americans care about lowering their overall costs more than keeping a private insurance plan.

Mr. Pollin said senior Warren campaign policy staffers have called him in recent weeks asking questions about different ways to finance Medicare for All. He declined to go into specifics. “I don’t know why they started to get in touch with me, but it’s really been just a couple of phone calls,” Mr. Pollin said.

Mr. Biden, who has aired ads touting his more incremental approach to health care, has taken aim at Ms. Warren for not explaining how she would pay for Medicare for All. “You can’t beat Trump by not being straightforward,” he said in an exchange with a Warren supporter at a stop in Iowa.

“Let’s at least acknowledge, let’s tell Elizabeth it’s going to cost a lot of money, and she’s going to raise people’s taxes doing it,” he said.

Ms. Warren was pressed on how to pay for government-run insurance in late September by Stephen Colbert during an appearance on “The Late Show.” Asked the same question by a New Hampshire voter last month, Ms. Warren responded that the U.S. “can afford health care for our citizens,” saying “really wealthy people are going to see their costs go up.”

—Ken Thomas contributed to this article.

Write to Joshua Jamerson at joshua.jamerson@wsj.com and Tarini Parti at Tarini.Parti@wsj.com
